fields.title: Intermediate French II
fields.school: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
fields.description: n/a
fields.prereq: FRE 201 Intermediate French I (667) (C- and above)

fields.title: Mineralogy
fields.description: This course in mineralogy will provide the students with the necessary fundamentals which are required for following courses in petrology and geology of ore deposits.

fields.title: Geologic Maps and Cross-Sections
fields.description: This course on geologic maps and cross-sections will introduce the students to the reading of topographic and geologic maps, to the identification of geologic structures on geologic maps, as well as to the construction of cross-sections.
fields.prereq: GEOL 101 Fundamentals of Geology (4774) (D and above) OR GEOL 102 Fundamentals of Geology (4772) (D and above)

fields.title: Sedimentology and strartigraphy
fields.description: The content of this course is the following: (1) sedimentary processes and depositional environments; (2) sedimentary facies and paleoenvironments; (3) lithostratigraphic units, biostratigraphy, chronostratigraphy, and correlations; (4) introduction to sequence stratigraphy. This course will provide the students with a solid background in sedimentology, in particular concerning the formation and evolution of sedimentray rocks in the context of the rock cycle, the concepts of stratigraphy and the relation between sedimentary processes and geologic time, and the importance of sedimentology and stratigraphy in petroleum exploration.
fields.prereq: GEOL 101 Fundamentals of Geology (4774) (D and above) OR GEOL 102 Fundamentals of Geology (4772) (D and above) AND GEOL 202 Geologic Maps and Cross-Sections (5123) (D and above)

fields.title: Paleontology
fields.description: This course is a necessary complement to the course on Sedimentology and Stratigraphy. It will cover the major groups of organisms preserved as macrofossils and microfossils in the geologic record. During the laboratory, the characteristic fossils for each time period will be treated. It will also illustrate the applications of paleontology to such important fields as paleoclimate reconstruction or petroleum exploration. The aims of this paleontology course are: (1) to introduce the students to the major groups of macrofossils and microfossils; (2) discuss the occurrence of fossils in the geologic record in terms of the origins and the evolution of life in general as well as in each major fossil group, as well as of the mass extinction events which have affected the planet.
fields.prereq: GEOL 101 Fundamentals of Geology (4774) (D and above) OR GEOL 102 Fundamentals of Geology (4772) (D and above)

fields.title: Field Geology 1
fields.description: This course consists of ten days of field work in the Karatau region. The students will learn how to use geological equipment on the field. They will generate their own stratigraphic columns and geologic maps.
fields.prereq: GEOL 202 Geologic Maps and Cross-Sections (5123) (C- and above)

fields.title: Structural Geology
fields.description: This course will introduce the students to the mechanics of rock deformation, the recognition and interpretation of faults, folds, foliation, lineation, shear zones, mylonites, and other kinematic indicators, as well as to the regional structural geology.
fields.prereq: (GEOL 101 Fundamentals of Geology (4774) (D and above) OR GEOL 102 Fundamentals of Geology (4772) (D and above)) AND GEOL 202 Geologic Maps and Cross-Sections (5123) (D and above)

fields.title: Geophysics
fields.description: This course will introduce the fundamentals in the three main disciplines of geophysics ╤В╨е╨г gravimetry, seismology, and geomagnetism. The theory will be illustrated with applications in the geological sciences, in particular in mineral and petroleum exploration, and in groundwater resource assessment. An introduction to the interpretation of seismic profiles will be given, and the techniques of measurement in gravimetry and geomagnetism will be explained.
fields.prereq: GEOL 204 Sedimentology and strartigraphy (5475) (D and above)

fields.title: Geology of ore deposits
fields.description: The course has been organized by ore deposit type with an effort to integrate aspects of geodynamics, tectonics, petrology, mineralogy and physical chemistry which are important to establish genetic models for ore deposits. Examples from Kazakhstan are used as case studies for the laboratories when this is possible.
fields.prereq: GEOL 101 Fundamentals of Geology (4774) (D and above) OR GEOL 102 Fundamentals of Geology (4772) (D and above) OR GEOL 201 Mineralogy (5122) (D and above)

fields.title: Geodynamics
fields.description: This course will explore in details the dynamics of the Earth, including the core, the mantle, and the crust.
fields.prereq: GEOL 301 Igneous and metamorphic petrology (5886) (C and above) AND GEOL 303 Structural Geology (5874) (C and above)

fields.title: Geographic Information Systems
fields.description: Geographic Information Systems (GIS) are routinely used in a wide range of geological studies, including geological mapping and exploration projects.

fields.title: Environmental Geochemistry
fields.description: This course will cover fundamental aspects of physical chemistry relevant to heavy metal dispersion, radionuclide migration, and oil spill contamination.

fields.title: Hydrogeology
fields.description: This course will cover the fundamentals of physics required in hydrogeological studies as well as in groundwater resource management.

fields.title: Field Geology 2
fields.description: This course will consist of two weeks of field work in the Altai Mountains of East Kazakhstan. It will give the opportunity to the students to put into practice what they will have learned in igneous and metamorphic petrology, structural geology, geodynamics, geology of ore deposits, and geographic information systems.
fields.prereq: GEOL 303 Structural Geology (5874) (D and above) OR GEOL 301 Igneous and metamorphic petrology (5886) (D and above)

fields.title: Petroleum Geology and Geochemistry
fields.description: This introductory course to petroleum exploration will discuss the theories on the origin of petroleum, the composition and properties of petroleum.

fields.title: Water Resource Management
fields.description: This course will focus on the scientific basis for water resource management, including watershed delineation, hydrologic budget, contamination sources and water quality, water resource carrying capacity, wetlands protection, and the impact of climate change on the evolution of water resources. A local case study will be investigated by the students.

fields.title: Geostatistics
fields.description: This course introduces the practical applications of basic and advanced statistical methods. It will introduce different data collection, exploratory analysis and quality assurance methods. Deterministic and geostatistical interpolation methods will also be demonstrated.
fields.prereq: MATH 161 Calculus I (118) (C- and above)

fields.title: Research Project I
fields.description: This unit represents the first part of the final undergraduate research project of the students, who will produce a review of the bibliography related to their own research project. This review of the bibliography will be made under the guidance of their supervisors. At the end of the semester, the students will give a presentation in front of the professors of the department.

fields.title: Research Project II
fields.description: This unit represents the second part of the final undergraduate research project of the students, who will now concentrate on the Projects itself.  At the end of the semester, the students will give a presentation in front of the professors of the department.
fields.prereq: GEOL 404 Research Project I (6423) (C- and above)

fields.title: Beginning German
fields.school: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
fields.description: This course is for beginners. During the course we will focus on all 4 main skills of language-learning: reading, listening, writing and speaking as well as a 5th skill: audio-visual comprehension.

fields.title: Beginning German II
fields.description: Continuation of GER 101.
fields.prereq: GER 101 Beginning German (3173) (C- and above)

fields.title: Intermediate German I
fields.description: Continuation of GER 102.
fields.prereq: GER 102 Beginning German II (3335) (C- and above)

fields.title: The Mongol Empire
fields.school: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
fields.description: Chinggis Khan and his descendants built and ruled the largest land empire in history ╤В╨е╨г the Mongol Empire that left a profound imprint on Eurasia and the world.
fields.prereq: Subject "HST" BETWEEN 100 and 199 OR Subject "" BETWEEN 100 and 199 OR Subject "" BETWEEN 100 and 199 OR Subject "" BETWEEN 100 and 199

fields.title: Clash of Civilizations: Communities, Confessions and Empires in Central Europe, 1000-1890
fields.description: A survey of Central Europe from Christianization to the Enlightenment with an emphasis on interethnic and interfaith coexistence on the borderland between Catholic, Orthodox and Islamic civilization.

fields.title: History of the Soviet Union: Politics, Society, Culture
fields.description: This course adopts a three-pronged approach to the history of the Soviet Union. First, we will look at the political history of ╤В╨е╨йthe first socialist state,╤В╨е╨и assuming a bird╤В╨е╨╡s eye-view of the Soviet statesmen. Shifting gears in the middle of the term, we will explore the Soviet society, constructing our discussion around key themes of ╤В╨е╨йutopia,╤В╨е╨и ╤В╨е╨йnation,╤В╨е╨и ╤В╨е╨йdissent,╤В╨е╨и ╤В╨е╨йgender,╤В╨е╨и ╤В╨е╨йconsumption╤В╨е╨и and ╤В╨е╨йmemory.╤В╨е╨и Finally, we will turn our attention to Soviet culture, especially its ╤В╨е╨йpopular manifestations,╤В╨е╨и which had spawned out a language tying disparate parts of that multifaceted experience together

fields.title: Modern Turkey: from the Ottoman Empire to the Turkish Republic
fields.description: n/a

fields.title: Research Assistance
fields.description: The goal of this course is to help students gain hands-on knowledge of and experience in the methods and processes of academic historical research. Toward that end, those who register for this course will work under the supervision of a history faculty member, who will assign them various tasks (literature searches, literature reviews, primary source analyses, research reports, data management, etc.) related to a current, ongoing research project of theirs.
fields.prereq: HST 100 History of Kazakhstan (172) (B and above) AND Subject "HST" BETWEEN 100 and 499

fields.title: Empire, Nation and Identity in Nineteenth-Century Eurasia
fields.description: An upper-level seminar devoted to discussing questions of identity and nationalism in multinational empires prior to World War I1 in the empires of Eurasia.
fields.prereq: HST 100 History of Kazakhstan (172) (C- and above)

fields.title: Neither Red, Nor White: 1917 Revolution as a National Moment
fields.description: The course focuses on the national movements triggered by the 1917 revolution. It represents, first, an attempt to narrate the story of the cataclysms from the borderlands╤В╨е╨╡ perspective, second, to trace the impact of the national mobilization in the subsequent Soviet nation-building and, finally, to locate the memory thereof within the present╤В╨е╨гday political undertakings.
fields.prereq: HST 100 History of Kazakhstan (172) (D and above) AND Subject "HST" BETWEEN 200 and 300

fields.title: Stalinist Central Asia
fields.description: This course will introduce the students to the history of the early Soviet Central Asia from the October Revolution and civil war to the end of World War II through a variety of secondary and primary sources organized around the cross-cutting themes of state, nation, and modernization.

In this course will further develop the skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing in Kazakh in a range of predictable/ unpredictable situations and familiarize students with a range of new grammar structures. The class activities will focus on listening, speaking and students will be encouraged to practice reading and writing skills in their own time.
fields.prereq: KAZ 150 Basic Kazakh (1215) (C- and above) OR KLL "[B1.2] Intermediate"

fields.title: Academic Kazakh II
fields.school: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
fields.description: Students enrolled in Academic Kazakh II are expected to function at the B2 level after taking KAZ 201 Academic Kazakh. The goal of the course is to lead students to function well at the B2 level and make significant progress at the C1 level.
fields.prereq: KAZ 201 Academic Kazakh I (4561) (C- and above) OR KLL "[B2.2] Upper-Interm."

fields.title: Academic Speaking in Kazakh
fields.description: This course aimed to develop academic speaking and oral skills. During this course students will have opportunities to engage into interactive activities such us in-class conversations, discussions, they will  present their materials in Kazakh.
fields.prereq: KAZ 202 Academic Kazakh II (4562) (C- and above) OR KLL "[C1.1] Advanced"
fields.antireq: KAZ 212 Academic Writing in Kazakh (703) (C- and above)

fields.description: This course allows students to improve their academic writing in Kazakh language. The students will learn how to analyze popular scientific texts and comprehensively construct essays with academic content.
fields.prereq: KAZ 202 Academic Kazakh II (4562) (C- and above) OR KLL "[C1.1] Advanced"

fields.prereq: KAZ 202 Academic Kazakh II (4562) (C- and above) OR KLL "[C1.1] Advanced"

fields.prereq: KAZ 202 Academic Kazakh II (4562) (C- and above) OR KLL "[C1.1] Advanced"

fields.description: The purpose of the course is deepening student learning Abai╤В╨е╨╡s literary legacy.
fields.prereq: KAZ 202 Academic Kazakh II (4562) (C- and above) OR KLL "[C1.1] Advanced"

fields.prereq: KAZ 202 Academic Kazakh II (4562) (C- and above) OR KLL "[C1.1] Advanced"

fields.title: Onomastics: History and Function of Names
fields.description: The course of onomastics gives basic knowledge on Kazakh onomastics. The juridical documents on onomastics in Kazakhstan are going to be compared with documents of other states. The course will widely discuss the onomastic units. Students will deal with scientific researches of geographical and administrative objects of their native or current living places. They will learn how to make scientific conclusions through the analysis of given information.
fields.prereq: KAZ 202 Academic Kazakh II (4562) (C- and above) OR KLL "[C1.1] Advanced"

fields.title: Contemporary Kazakh Literature
fields.description: It is important to analyze the effects of the historical and social changes on the development of society of the second half of the twentieth century, which contributes to the special part of the national history. In addition the importance of providing the characteristics for the general conditions of the literature at that time and explaining its main traits in details to the young students is quite significant. The major directions of the word art, life and creativity of writers and poets, the title and genre and other objectives in the duration between 1950 and 2000 of the Kazakh land are discussed in a wide range in this course.
fields.prereq: KAZ 202 Academic Kazakh II (4562) (C- and above) OR KLL "[C1.1] Advanced"

fields.title: Language and ethnicity
fields.school: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
fields.description: This course studies the connection between language and ethnos from the scientific viewpoint and considers the ethno cultural lexis as a tool to study the nation.
fields.prereq: KAZ 202 Academic Kazakh II (4562) (C- and above) OR KLL "[C1.1] Advanced"

fields.title: Kazakh Terminology
fields.school: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
fields.description: This course is developed to expand students╤В╨е╨╡ knowledge about Kazakh terminology. The course╤В╨е╨╡s content covers topics from the history of Kazakh terminology╤В╨е╨╡s development to the current situation. Future specialists will learn about enhancing terminology quality, experts who devoted themselves to the field, phases of the terminology evolution.
fields.prereq: KAZ 202 Academic Kazakh II (4562) (C- and above) OR KLL "[C1.1] Advanced"

fields.title: Kazakh Diplomacy
fields.description: The content of Kazakh diplomacy course consists of international relations of Kazakhstan and includes diplomatic negotiations, diplomatic protocols, diplomatic documentation, the formation of the state border.
fields.prereq: KAZ 202 Academic Kazakh II (4562) (C- and above) OR KLL "[C1.1] Advanced"

fields.title: Language and Culture
fields.description: The purpose of this course is to teach Kazakh culture through linguistic units.
fields.prereq: KAZ 202 Academic Kazakh II (4562) (C- and above) OR KLL "[C1.1] Advanced"

fields.title: Kazakh literature of the XV-XIX centuries
fields.description: Kazakh literature of the XV-XIX centuries is a course covering significant periods in the history of the national art of speech. In the content of the course the issues of artistic and stylistic continuity of traditional Zhyrau and poetic poetry are explained orally in a scientific and theoretical way.
fields.prereq: Subject "KAZ" BETWEEN 300 and 399 OR Subject "KAZ" BETWEEN 300 and 399

fields.title: Elementary Kazakh as a Foreign Language I
fields.school: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
fields.description: Beginning Kazakh as a foreign language.

fields.title: Intermediate Kazakh as a Foreign Language II
fields.description: Intermediate Kazakh as a foreign language II.
fields.prereq: KFL 201 Intermediate Kazakh as a Foreign Language I (4887) (C- and above)

fields.title: Beginning Korean I
fields.description: This course is for beginners. During the course we will focus on all 4 main skills of language-learning: reading, listening, writing and speaking.

fields.title: Beginning Korean II
fields.school: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
fields.description: Continuation of KOR 101.
fields.prereq: KOR 101 Beginning Korean I (4672) (C- and above)

fields.title: Intermediate Korean I
fields.description: Continuation of KOR 102.
fields.prereq: KOR 102 Beginning Korean II (4791) (C- and above)

fields.title: Intermediate Korean II
fields.description: Continuation of KOR 201.
fields.prereq: KOR 201 Intermediate Korean I (5059) (C- and above)

fields.title: Advanced Korean I
fields.description: KOR 301 will provide Academic Korean for those who plan to study Korean at higher educational institutions in the future or for those who want to obtain academic knowledge of the language and to develop academic language skills such as making presentations, participating in group discussions, listening to lectures, note-taking, summarizing lectures, reading and writing academic papers.
fields.prereq: KOR 202 Intermediate Korean II (5060) (C- and above)

fields.title: Introduction to Language and Communication
fields.school: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
fields.description: The course offers a description of the communicational functions of language, the pragmatics of language and language variation. The course also covers the basics of discourse and conversation analyses.

fields.title: Introduction to Linguistics
fields.description: n/a

fields.title: Language Variation and Change: the Story of English
fields.description: The course offers an introduction to comparative-historical linguistics by identifying and describing variation and change of the English language. The course will focus on sound change, history of words and the evolution of grammar of the English language. Within the course the students will also become aware of language variation and discuss the role of English as the global language.

fields.title: Introduction to Sociolinguistics
fields.description: This first year introductory course is meant to establish students╤В╨е╨╡ understanding of central themes and topics in the field, in order to support their continued coursework in upper division sociolinguistics courses. Language is not just a static repository of grammar rules and vocabulary, but rather a diverse and ever-changing means of expression for individuals, communities, countries, and global networks. In this course we explore the nature of variation both within and across languages ╤В╨е╨г how different ways of using language(s) can be meaningful and essential for our ever-shifting politics, cultures, and an increasingly interconnected world.

fields.title: Language and the Mind
fields.description: The course will focus on how language is represented and processed in the human brain.

fields.title: Survey of Research Methods in Linguistics
fields.description: This course examines the manner in which language data and linguistic knowledge is produced and analyzed.
fields.prereq: LING 131 Introduction to Linguistics (1394) (C- and above)

fields.title: Language Diversity and Language Universals
fields.school: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
fields.description: The course teaches students about the linguistic diversity in the world and explains the differences and similarities among the world languages.

fields.title: Sounds of the World╤В╨е╨╡s Languages
fields.description: This course is an introduction to the fundamentals of phonetics and phonology. It will examine the range of sounds used in the major world╤В╨е╨╡s languages (e.g. English, Spanish, Russian, etc) and the ways they are used. The course will be useful for students interested in linguistics and foreign languages.

fields.title: Language Contact in Central Asia
fields.description: This course will explore contacts between languages from the perspective of general linguistics and social linguistics. In this course, students will learn core concepts in language contact. We will also consider specific case studies from languages all over the world, and reflect on cases studies in Central Asian language contact. This course focuses on developing the students╤В╨е╨╡ abilities to formulate research questions and proposals as well. Students will examine their hypothesis by field work.

fields.title: The Art and Science of Analyzing Languages: Morphosyntax of the World's Languages
fields.description: The course teaches the methods for analyzing morphosyntax of the world╤В╨е╨╡s languages with an ample range of linguistic examples and practical exercises.
fields.prereq: LING 131 Introduction to Linguistics (1394) (C- and above)

fields.title: Psycholinguistics
fields.description: Psychology of Language is an interdisciplinary field in which it covers the perception and production of language, reading written language, processing sentences, mental lexicon and first /second plus language acquisitions.
fields.prereq: LING 131 Introduction to Linguistics (1394) (C- and above) OR LING 272 Language and the Mind (1847) (C- and above) OR LING 273 Survey of Research Methods in Linguistics (2158) (C- and above)

fields.title: Multilingualism and Language Contact
fields.school: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
fields.description: This course studies phenomena related to multilingualism and language contact, and its consequences.
fields.prereq: LING 131 Introduction to Linguistics (1394) (C- and above) OR LING 270 Languages of Eurasia (2485) (C- and above) OR ANT 277/WLL 271 Language and Society (1027) (C- and above) OR LING 272 Language and the Mind (1847) (C- and above) OR LING 273 Survey of Research Methods in Linguistics (2158) (C- and above) OR LING 274 Introduction to Applied Linguistics (2486) (C- and above) OR LING 275 Second Language Acquisition Theory and Research I (4473) (C- and above)

fields.title: Language Ideologies
fields.description: How do beliefs and perceptions about what language is or should be structure our use and understanding of individual speakers and speech communities?  What is the relationship between language and structures of power? This course introduces students to the study of Language Ideology, one of the primary topics of study in linguistic anthropology, which connects the semiotic study of sign forms not only to the cohesion and coherence of language in its various modalities (spoken, written, signed), but also to the social and historical relations structuring our categories and understanding of the object ╤В╨е╨┤language╤В╨е╨╡ in itself.
fields.prereq: LING 131 Introduction to Linguistics (1394) (C- and above)

fields.title: Computer Aided Design
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: Computer Aided Design is a core course for 2nd-year students with the main focus on the fundamentals of engineering design: visualization, sketching, drawing, modeling, prototyping, assembling, and testing.

fields.title: Material and Manufacturing I
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: This course primarily intends to introduce the students to a wide variety of materials and relevant theories. This course covers ferrous & non-ferrous materials and three other major categories of non-metallic materials namely ceramics, polymers and composite. Students will be introduced to the idea of production processes required for various materials. Different types of heat treatment processes such as annealing, normalizing, quenching, tempering, surface modification methods to improvise material properties further will be introduced.

fields.title: Engineering Dynamics I
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description:
The key focus areas are:
a)	Model and analyze the kinematics of systems of rigid bodies.
b)	Model and analyze dynamic interactions of rigid bodies.	
c)	Apply the principle of work and energy for rigid bodies in complex motion.
d)	Apply the principle of impulse and momentum for rigid bodies in complex motion.
e)	Model and analyze three dimensional rigid body systems (introduction).

fields.title: Fluid Mechanics I
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: The course is concerned with the static and dynamics of liquids and gases. The analysis of the behavior of fluids is based upon the fundamental laws of applied mechanics that relate to the conservation of mass, energy and momentum equations. The triad of integral, differential, and experimental approaches is being employed throughout the entire course.
fields.prereq: PHYS 161 Physics I for Scientists and Engineers with Laboratory (116) (D and above)

fields.title: Engineering Thermodynamics
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: This course covers all the standard essentials of engineering thermodynamics as is found in most standard university courses. The course has a bias towards the essentials for mechanical engineering students.

fields.title: Machine Elements Design
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: The module aims to impart the necessary knowledge and skills for mechanical engineering students to analyse and design machine elements and simple machines
fields.prereq: MAE 205 Material and Manufacturing I (5534) (D and above)

fields.title: Control Systems
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: The course aims to provide a solid background for the understanding of classical controller, its analysis and design techniques. It will help students in developing hardware and software packages.

fields.title: Fluid Mechanics II
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: The module focuses on the fundamental concepts, principles and theories of external flows, boundary layers, compressible flows, and turbomachinery.
fields.prereq: MAE 300 Fluid Mechanics I (5926) (D and above) OR EME 275 Fluid Mechanics I (1988) (D and above)

fields.title: Computer Aided Engineering
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: The course is aiming to introduce the fundamentals of the Finite and Boundary Element methods (FEM / BEM) and guide students in the development and usage of such methods in the engineering profession. Focus will be given in solving specific engineering problems ranging from solid mechanics, to heat transfer and fluid flows using both student-developed and commercial analysis software packages.
fields.prereq: ENG 202 Numerical Methods in Engineering (5506) (D and above) AND MAE 201 Computer Aided Design (5011) (D and above)

fields.title: Engineering Dynamics II
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: The course consists of analysis of machines and mechanisms operation with application of statics and dynamics principles. Application of these principles with analysis of operation of mechanisms provides background for design of machine elements. Also gear theory will be introduced, balancing of shaking forces and crank effort diagram and flywheels. Finally, mechanical vibration in machine elements will be explained to define the natural frequency, transient and steady state responses.
fields.prereq: MAE 206 Engineering Dynamics I (5535) (D and above)

fields.title: Structural Mechanics II
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description:
Structural mechanics II aims to study plasticity, brittle vs ductile failure modes, composite materials, fast fracture, fatigue, creep, and instability of structures such as buckling of columns. A theoretical introduction to the finite element method will be delivered.
Students shall be able to develop critical thinking skills and identify the failure mode of a structure
fields.prereq: MAE 200 Structural Mechanics I (5010) (D and above) OR CEE 200 Structural Mechanics I (5005) (D and above)

fields.title: Vehicle Propulsion Systems
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: Introduction of the most important concepts of mathematical system modelling using vehicle propulsion problems as examples, both with traditional energy sources and clean-energy sources. Presentation of several model classes of propulsion systems and components will be given. Application of modern system components and control tools to vehicle propulsion systems will be included.
fields.prereq: MAE 301 Engineering Thermodynamics (5927) (D and above) OR BENG 226 Engineering Thermodynamics (1553) (D and above)

fields.title: Heat Transfer
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: The course covers the heat transfer phenomena including conduction, convection and radiation. Boiling and condensation, and heat exchangers are treated as well. By learning the basis of all these phenomena and techniques, the students will develop advance knowledge and understanding of heat transfer. The module will assist students to gain an understanding of heat transfer concepts and their applications.
fields.prereq: MAE 300 Fluid Mechanics I (5926) (D and above) AND MAE 301 Engineering Thermodynamics (5927) (D and above)

fields.title: Mechanical Systems Design
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: The course will consist of application and enhancement of previously studied principles of machine elements design (MAE 302 course) to design complex mechanical systems and machines. Teaching methods will include group assignments, peer learning.
fields.prereq: MAE 302 Machine Elements Design (5928) (D and above)

fields.title: Additive Manufacturing
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: This course aims to present & study Additive Manufacturing (AM) technologies such as Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM), Stereolithography (SLA) and Selective Laser Melting (SLM), as well as an overview of AM and industry 4.0. The module includes a presentation of the different materials available for use with these technologies, such as photopolymer resins, plastic filaments for FDM printing and metal powders for metal AM, i.e., SLM. The production and properties of metal powders will be studied in detail. Topology optimization for 3D printing will be also covered in this module. Project-based learning is a major component in this course and therefore project assignments, lab experimentation and practical sessions will be used to develop student skills in designing for AM, critical thinking in reviewing models for AM and assessing the pros and cons of each applicable approach and technique. Formal assessment is carried out via 2 mini-projects (25 and 50%) and a final examination (25%).
fields.prereq: MAE 205 Material and Manufacturing I (5534) (D and above)

fields.title: Fire Engineering
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description:
The Fire Engineering course aims to:
1) Provide a general understanding of the principles of enclosure fire dynamics, 
2) Help the students to appreciate their applications to building fires and smoke analysis, 
3) Familiarize the students with the basic design methods for fire-fighting systems.
fields.prereq: MAE 305 Fluid Mechanics II (6173) (D and above) AND MAE 301 Engineering Thermodynamics (5927) (D and above)

fields.title: Aerodynamics
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description:
1) Familiarization of students with the basic principles of the concepts, techniques and theory for the analysis of aerodynamics.
2) Development of various relevant skills and competences through the application of aerodynamics to the design of engineering components and systems 
3) Familiarization and development of Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) models associated to aerodynamics engineering applications.
fields.prereq: MAE 305 Fluid Mechanics II (6173) (D and above)

fields.title: Flight Mechanics
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description:
By the end of the course the student will be expected to be able to:
1)	Understand airplane flight conditions and stability. 
2)	Analyze airplane flight performance in various conditions. 
3)	Relate the various physical elements and environmental parameters which govern the design and performance of airplane. 
4)	Appreciate space flight and hypersonic vehicles.
fields.prereq: MAE 305 Fluid Mechanics II (6173) (D and above) AND MAE 301 Engineering Thermodynamics (5927) (D and above)

fields.title: Materials and Manufacturing II
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: This course is designed to provide students with an overview of a wide variety of manufacturing processes (additive, forming & subtractive) and system including assembly. It will also provide the insight of fundamental principle behind the manufacturing processes. This course includes project work which requires student to generate G coding and fabricate part product using computer numerical controlled (CNC), machine.

fields.title: Advanced Topics in Computational Fluid Dynamics
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description:
1. Review fundamental governing differential equations in incompressible fluid dynamics and energy conservation, both in Vector and Cartesian-tensor notation.
2. Introduce concept of Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) and learn computational hardware & software and space-time discretization schemes generally associated to it by programming own small codes and by using commercial software widely used for engineering applications.
3. Introduce some advanced topics in CFD, such as turbulence modelling, radiation and combustion modeling, multiphase modeling, computational fluid structure interaction and most popular methods used in engineering applications.
fields.prereq: MAE 300 Fluid Mechanics I (5926) (D and above) AND ENG 202 Numerical Methods in Engineering (5506) (D and above)

fields.title: Multiphase Systems
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: This course will identify the industrial occurrence of the simultaneous flow of more than one phase and highlight the implications for design.  The course will cover the basic principles, engineering models and equations of multi-phase flows and selected multi-phase systems.
fields.prereq: MAE 300 Fluid Mechanics I (5926) (D and above) AND MAE 305 Fluid Mechanics II (6173) (D and above)

fields.title: Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems and Microsystems technology
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: The course aims to introduce MEMS devices, microsystems and their applications. The course will start with an introduction to the working principles of microsystems. It will follow up with the microsystems design and fabrication. Some representative sensors (pressure, toque and flow) will be presented to demonstrate the application and advantages of such miniaturized devices.

fields.title: Mechanics of Soft Materials
fields.school: School of Engineering and Digital Sciences
fields.description: This course provides a brief background on materials chemistry and will then shift toward the chemical and physical properties of polymers, with a focus on mechanical properties. Effects of chemical structure and morphology on thermal and mechanical properties as well as the behavior of materials under stress, will be discussed in depth. A fundamental understanding of the corresponding characterization techniques (DMA, DSC, TGA, Mass Spectrometry, and FTIR) will be covered.
fields.prereq: ENG 102 Engineering Materials I (4708) (D and above)

fields.title: Mathematical Discovery
fields.description: This course is to explore applications of mathematics in real life, including social choice and management science, showing that math is more than a set of formulas.
fields.antireq: MATH 161 Calculus I (118) (C- and above)

fields.title: Abstract Algebra I
